instruction: What medicine should I take when I get a cold?
output:
Taking cold medicine might help you feel better, but the common cold usually goes away on its own in a week or two. Most cold medicines treat only symptoms, not the cold itself. Check with your doctor before giving any cold medicine to children, and don't give aspirin to anyone younger than 20 unless directed by a doctor.
Over-the-counter (OTC) cold medicines can be used to treat the symptoms of colds in adults and children 2 years and older. There are many types of OTC cold medicines, including decongestants, antihistamines, and pain relievers. Decongestants can help clear a stuffy nose. Antihistamines can reduce sneezing and itchy eyes. Pain relievers can help reduce fever and aches.
Decongestants may make you drowsy, so be careful when driving or operating heavy machinery. Don’t take more than the recommended dose. Don’t give antihistamines to children under 4 years of age unless directed by a doctor.
Also, don’t give aspirin to children because it has been linked to Reye syndrome, a rare condition that causes damage to the liver and brain.
In addition to over-the-counter medicines, there are some prescription medicines for colds. These include antiviral medicines that fight against the virus that causes the common cold. They may shorten the length of your cold, but they won’t cure it. Talk to your doctor about whether one of these medicines might be right for you.

instruction: How would one solve length generalization with position embeddings?
output:
I have a dataset of hand-drawn human poses. I am using position embeddings to represent the positions of key points in a person's body (e.g. head, shoulders, elbows, knees). I want to train my model on 1000 samples and test it on an additional set of 500 samples. The goal is to classify these poses into predefined categories like sitting, standing etc.

However, when I evaluate the model on the test data, I notice that it performs poorly on the longer poses (e.g. someone sitting with their legs crossed) as opposed to shorter poses (e.g. someone standing).

What would be a good way to address this problem?

One possible solution could be to use a multi-step approach where we first fine-tune the model on the training data for a few epochs and then freeze all the parameters except the ones related to the positional embeddings. We can then update the positional embeddings using the new data by either adding more data points or using some sort of proxy task like learning to predict the next key point given the previous one. Finally, we can unfreeze all the parameters and fine-tune the model again.

The good news is that you don’t have to be a victim of stress – in fact, there are many things you can do to decrease your stress levels. By making simple lifestyle changes, you can reduce workplace stress and maintain your sanity.
1. Relieve stress by getting organized.: The key to reducing stress at work is to eliminate the chaos that comes from disorganization. A clean work space also gives you a sense of control over your environment.
Ask your employer if you can designate a specific folder for incoming paperwork, so you know where to look for it. Fill folders with related materials, such as items requesting the same action from you. Label files and drawers so you can quickly identify them, especially if you work in a large office.
Keep a to-do list or schedule. Crossing completed items/tasks off will give you a sense of satisfaction. You can use a whiteboard, a piece of paper, or an app to keep track of your tasks. Keep your list simple, so you can easily refer to it throughout the day.
2. Relieve stress by being realistic.: When you set goals for yourself, make sure they’re achievable. Not only will setting realistic goals help you avoid disappointment, but it will prevent you from feeling rushed or stressed. If you find yourself overwhelmed, reevaluate your goals

instruction: Can you briefly explain this concept of computational irreducibility?
output:
I am studying the concept of computational irreducibility. I came across this concept while reading a paper (https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~rwh/papers/fibrank.pdf).
The paper introduces the concept using the following example:

Given a function $f:\{0,1\}^n\rightarrow\{0,1\}$ that is defined by a boolean circuit of size $s(n)$ and depth $d(n)$. A function $g:\{0,1\}^n\rightarrow\{0,1\}^m$ is called $T$-computably reducible to $f$ if there exists a boolean circuit $C$ of size $t(n)$ and depth $d(n)$ such that $C$ computes $g$ and $C$ can be converted into a boolean circuit of size $s'(n)$ and depth $d'(n)$ that computes $\mathrm{poly}(m)f$.

What I don't understand is why do we consider the case when we restrict our attention to circuits that compute functions with fixed inputs? In other words, why can't we consider the case where the input size of the given circuit is also part of the input to the computation?

3. More personalized communication. People can make their hologram look however they want, so they can choose to resemble someone else if they want to. This could lead to more accurate representations of people in hologram form.

5. More immersive entertainment. Holograms can be used to create more realistic and immersive experiences than traditional forms of entertainment, such as movies or video games.
Overall, this new technology would have a major impact on society, both positive and negative. It would change the way people communicate, interact, and experience entertainment.

instruction: What language family does Hungarian belong to?
output:
Welcome to the Hungarian language page! Here you will find information about the Hungarian language, where it is spoken and some common phrases.
Hungarian belongs to the Ugric group of languages that are part of the Finno-Ugric family of languages, which also includes Estonian and Finnish. These languages are unrelated to any other language families in Europe. Hungarian is spoken by approximately 14 million people, mostly in Hungary, but also in parts of Romania, Slovakia, Serbia, Ukraine, and Austria. It is an agglutinative language, meaning that words are formed by adding suffixes and prefixes to roots or stems. Hungarian has a complex system of vowel harmony, which is one of its distinguishing features.

instruction: What to do about clingy toddlers?
output:
A toddler who clings to their parent may be showing signs of separation anxiety. This is a natural stage in a toddler’s development and can often occur when the child starts preschool or daycare. However, if your toddler is clingy all the time, it can be difficult for both you and your child. Fortunately, there are ways to help soothe your toddler’s fears and help him learn to separate from you while still keeping him safe.
1. Identify why your child is clingy.: Clinginess is a common behavior in young children. Often, toddlers become clingy for no discernible reason other than they want attention. However, there are other reasons why your toddler may be clingy:

Your toddler may be experiencing separation anxiety. When a child becomes more independent, he may feel anxious about being apart from his parents or caregivers. As a result, he may hold on to you as much as possible.
Your toddler may be scared or overwhelmed by a new situation. If your toddler has recently started preschool or daycare, he may cling to you because he is unsure of what to expect.
Your toddler may have difficulty sleeping. Being overtired can cause a toddler to act out, including clinging to his parents. Make sure your toddler gets enough sleep at night so that he doesn’t have to rely on excessive clinginess to get his needs met.

instruction: Compare better call saul and breaking bad. What does each show do better than the other?
output:
Breaking Bad is a more cohesive, consistent, and well-written show. Better Call Saul doesn't quite reach the same heights as Breaking Bad, but it still offers great acting, mostly interesting characters, and a compelling story. Both shows have some similarities, but they also have their differences. Breaking Bad has stronger characters, but Better Call Saul has better pacing and more complex plotlines.
In terms of acting, both shows have impressive casts, with standout performances from Bryan Cranston as Walter White in Breaking Bad and Bob Odenkirk as Saul Goodman in Better Call Saul. However, Better Call Saul offers more depth to its supporting characters, particularly Jonathan Banks as Mike Ehrmantraut.
While Breaking Bad tells a more straightforward story, Better Call Saul takes a more nuanced approach, exploring the moral ambiguity of its characters and their motivations. The two shows also differ in their pacing, with Better Call Saul taking a slower approach to build up its plotline, while Breaking Bad moves at a faster pace, with each episode feeling like a self-contained story.
Overall, while Breaking Bad remains the superior show, Better Call Saul is worth watching for its strong acting, complex storylines, and exploration of morality.

instruction: What's the best way to learn how to make latte art?
output:
As a barista, your main goal is to make customers happy. One way to do this is by learning how to make latte art. There are different types of latte art you can make, including the popular heart and rosettas. You can learn these techniques in a few different ways; there are many online tutorials you can follow, as well as videos on YouTube. Additionally, you can ask your local coffee shop trainer or manager if they have any resources available for you to learn latte art.
1. Head to a coffee shop and ask for help.: Many shops have "baristas in training" who are just starting to learn how to make latte art, and would be happy to teach you what they know. You can also approach a more experienced barista and ask them if they have time to teach you some tips. If you'd rather learn at home, but still want feedback, consider asking a friend who drinks lattes to try your latte art and give you some pointers.
You should also consider taking an actual class. There are many offered online, through universities and community colleges, and even through some coffee shops.
2. Look up tutorials on YouTube or read articles on websites.: There are tons of tutorials available online. Though it may seem weird to watch someone else make latte art on YouTube, remember that you can rewind the video if you mess something up! Also, pay attention to different baristas and their unique styles of creating latte art. Once you get good at making basic patterns, try branching out and trying more advanced latte art. Bowling is a game of physics. Yes, physics!
1. The key to throwing the ball down the lane with accuracy is to practice your approach. If you take a few steps towards the foul line and raise the ball up over your head, you will be putting unnecessary backswing into your delivery. You should always start walking as close to the foul line as possible and begin raising the ball high enough over your head to deliver it accurately.
When you’re approaching the line, swing the ball in a circular motion so that when you release it, it’s pointing directly at the pins. Practice this move until it feels natural and you can execute it without even thinking about it.
2. Your aim should be to throw the ball at an angle. Throwing it straight down the lane means that it has to travel farther before reaching the pins and gives you less time to make adjustments for any disturbances on the lane. Aim to throw the ball at an angle of around 30 degrees to the right or left of the foul line. If you do this, you’ll be able to keep your ball rolling down the lane for longer.
If you’re unsure which way to turn your arm, aim for the second arrow from the right (for a right-handed bowler) or the second arrow from the left (for a left-handed bowler). Hold the ball at arm's length with both hands and line it up with the arrows. Then, turn your hand and arm so that the fingers are facing towards the third arrow from the left (for right-handers) or the third arrow from the right (for left-handers).

instruction: How do I make poached eggs at home?
output:
If you’ve never made a poached egg at home before, it might seem like a complicated process. But, in reality, it is one of the easiest things to cook because all you need are a few ingredients and a pot of boiling water.
1. Crack eggs into a small bowl and add about 1 to 2 tablespoons of cold water. Beat the eggs with a fork until they have a uniform, smooth consistency. To make an omlette you can beat in some milk and seasoning, which makes them even tastier.
You can also use a whisk to break up the eggs if you don’t have a fork.
2. Put a saucepan over medium-high heat and fill it with water so that it reaches about 3 inches (8 cm) deep. You should be able to place at least one finger between the surface of the water and the bottom of the pan without touching the bottom of the pan.
Make sure that the water doesn’t reach too high. Place a lid on the pan. This will stop a lot of steam from getting out, which means that your eggs won’t end up being overcooked.
3. Gently slide your eggs into the pan once the water is hot. Cook for about 6 minutes. Use a slotted spoon to take the eggs out of the pan when they are done.
4. Serve with your preferred side dishes. Enjoy!

instruction: I have 350 examples that were annotated with binary labels by two different annotators. How do I compute inter-annotator agreement, including confidence interval?
output:
While working with a dataset of 350 examples, we found that two different annotators gave binary labels to the examples. We would like to compute inter-annotator agreement and confidence interval on those annotations.
What is the best way to do this?
The easiest way to calculate inter-rater reliability between two raters is to use the Krippendorff's alpha (α). It ranges from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating better agreement. You can calculate it in R or Python using the following formulas:
Krippendorff's alpha for a dichotomous scale:
$$ \alpha = \frac{a_{true} + a_{false}}{n} $$
where $a_{true}$ is the number of agreed responses, $a_{false}$ is the number of disagreed responses, and $n$ is the total number of responses.
Krippendorff's alpha for a rating scale:
$$ \alpha = 1 - \frac{\sum_i^n w_i (f_i - \bar{f})}{\sqrt{\sum_i^n w_i (f_i - \bar{f})^2}} $$
where $f_i$ is the rating given by rater i, $\bar{f}$ is the mean rating across all raters, $w_i$ is the weight of rater i's rating (e.g., 1 if they are both experts, 0.5 if they are both beginners), and $n$ is the total number of ratings.
You can find more details and code to calculate Krippendorff's alpha here:
https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/296154/how-to-calculate-krippendorffs-alpha-coefficient-for-inter-r

instruction: What is the difference between you and a human?
output:
New research in the journal Science Robotics shows how robots can be trained to identify objects by "understanding" their context, rather than just being told what they are.
The study demonstrates a robot identifying an object based on the context of where it is located within a scene -- and then correctly labeling it when faced with a new instance of that same object in a different location.
Experts say this is a significant step towards machines gaining human-like visual perception abilities.
Researchers from the University of California, Berkeley, and the Max Planck Institute for Informatics in Saarbrücken, Germany, said this was the first time a robot had been trained in this way.
"What we're doing is using the context of an object to help build an understanding of what the object is," said Prof Stuart Russell, one of the authors of the study.
"We're not just telling the robot, 'this is a table', but instead saying, 'this is a table here, and a table there'," he told BBC News.
"And then when we put a table somewhere else, it will figure out what kind of table it is because it's seen so many instances of it."
Prof Russell said scientists were still a long way off from creating robots that could understand objects in the same rich, nuanced way humans do, but this new study took them a step closer to achieving that goal.
"A person who has never seen an object before - say, a pine cone - would look at it and have no idea what it is. But if you show it to a child, that child will pick it up and look at it and turn it over and look at it from all sorts of angles. As a result of that experience, the child will have formed a much deeper understanding of what a pine cone is," he said.

instruction: Does the world have enough drinking water for everyone? How much do we have? How much more do we need?
output:
Droughts have been in the news a lot recently. Environmentalists warn that two-thirds of the world's population could be facing water shortages by 2025 if we don't take steps to conserve our limited supply. But is there really a global water crisis?
Yes, a global water crisis is underway, though it varies a lot from place to place. In the U.S., it's mostly a Western problem. California has been struggling with drought for years, and its situation is dire. The state is now considering rationing urban water use. Elsewhere, the Great Lakes region is also running into problems due to aging infrastructure, as well as poor stewardship in places like Flint, Mich.
But even in these regions, water crises are not inevitable. Both California and the Great Lakes states have already taken important steps, such as investing in better water conservation technology, reducing urban water use through pricing reforms, and building new reservoirs that can capture stormwater runoff. These steps have helped ease shortages in other parts of the year.
In many other parts of the world, however, water shortages are much more severe. Two billion people -- about one in four of all the people on the planet -- live in riverside areas that lack reliable access to clean drinking water. And nearly 80 percent of the water used globally goes to irrigating crops, leaving relatively little for people and ecosystems.
This pattern may change in the near future. Climate change is expected to reduce surface water availability in many parts of the world, while increasing rainfall and flooding in others. This will likely lead to more water disputes between nations, as well as within countries, where farmers and cities could both demand more water.

instruction: I'm looking for a game to play with a large group of friends.
output:
Between 5 and 10 players.
I've never played it but I've been told that it's really fun.
It is pretty fun, we called it "drunkie" back in college when we played it, I think the original name is "Amnesia".
Basically everyone picks a number between 1-100 and those are the points you're aiming for. You take turns drawing cards from a deck of 104 (4x27) and try to get as close to your number as possible with the card values adding up to your number. So if you have 79 points and draw an Ace of Spades which is worth 11, you can either keep it or discard it since your score is now 88 (Ace is wild).
The cool part is there are 3 different decks, and you can play multiple rounds with the same group adding up your scores at the end of each round. It is pretty easy to teach, and once you start playing, it flies by.

You might want to consider getting one that also has a charcoal filter, which will absorb any additional odors in the air.

instruction: I'm thinking of taking my family to Disney World, but I'm not sure when the best time of year is. Can you recommend a time of year that is inexpensive but not too crowded?
output:
The best time to visit Walt Disney World depends upon what you are looking for. The two largest factors affecting crowds are school breaks and the weather. School breaks will dictate how many large family groups are at the parks, with spring break being the busiest time. Summertime will be the next busiest, with the exception of the week between Christmas and New Years.
Weather is another factor to consider. While a rainy day isn't likely to keep most people from having fun, it can cause long waits for attractions. In addition, August and September can bring oppressive heat and high humidity. It's also important to note that crowd levels vary from park to park. For instance, Magic Kingdom gets much more crowded than Epcot during the busy times because it's a very popular park with families.
There are some off-peak times when it's still possible to take advantage of lower prices, but crowds at the parks are larger. January and February is one of these times. You'll find rooms at the Value Resorts for under $75 a night, but expect higher crowds overall. If you're not bothered by cooler temperatures, early November and mid-April are other good times to visit. There are generally holidays in November (Thanksgiving) and April (Easter), which increases crowds for those weeks, but the price drops for the rest of the month.
If you're interested in crowd levels, check out my blog post: Crowd Calendar - A better way to plan your trip. This calendar shows estimated crowds based on historical data, and allows you to see how crowds are expected to be each day of your trip.

instruction: Create a lesson plan for teaching the works of S. Y. Agnon.

2. Choose a specific work by Agnon to focus on, such as A Simple Story or The Bridal Canopy. Read the work aloud to your students, stopping periodically to discuss key themes, characters, and plot points.

instruction: What are the main differences between Python and JavaScript programming languages?
output:
A programming language is a set of instructions written in a specific syntax that can be interpreted and executed by a computer. Python and JavaScript are two popular programming languages used for web development, data analysis, and artificial intelligence. Here are some of the main differences between Python and JavaScript:
1. Syntax: Python uses whitespace indentation to define blocks of code, while JavaScript uses curly braces. Python code is typically more readable due to its simplicity, while JavaScript code can be more complex due to its ability to use functional programming techniques.
2. Object-oriented programming: Python is a fully object-oriented programming language, while JavaScript has some object-oriented features but is primarily a prototype-based language. This means that JavaScript code can be more difficult to read and maintain compared to Python code.
3. Data structures: Python has a built-in data structure called lists, which is similar to arrays in JavaScript. However, Python also has dictionaries, sets, and tuples, which are not available in JavaScript. Additionally, JavaScript has a more extensive library of built-in functions than Python.
4. Web development: Both Python and JavaScript are widely used for web development, but Python is often preferred for back-end development due to its ability to handle large amounts of data and its support for various web frameworks such as Flask and Django. JavaScript, on the other hand, is primarily used for front-end development, including creating interactive user interfaces and animations.
5. Machine learning: Python is commonly used for machine learning because it has a wide range of libraries and tools for data analysis and statistical modeling. In contrast, JavaScript is not typically used for machine learning, although it can still be used for data visualization and interaction.
Overall, while both Python and JavaScript have their strengths and weaknesses, they are both versatile programming languages that can be used for a variety of applications.

instruction: What are the most effective strategies for conflict resolution in the workplace?
output:
Given that conflict resolution is an important component of successful management, it is crucial to understand which methods work best. While there are many different approaches to resolving conflicts, some are more effective than others. Mediation and arbitration are two popular conflict resolution strategies used in the workplace.
Mediation involves a neutral third-party facilitating discussions between the parties involved in the conflict. The goal of mediation is to help both sides reach a mutually beneficial agreement. This strategy can be particularly useful when the parties involved have a professional relationship and need to continue working together. In addition to helping to diffuse tensions, mediation allows for both sides to express their concerns and needs in a safe and respectful manner.
Arbitration is similar to mediation, but instead of a neutral third-party facilitating discussions, an arbitrator will make a binding decision based on the evidence presented. This strategy is often used when there is already a established dispute resolution process in place, such as in a collective bargaining agreement. Arbitration can be helpful in resolving conflicts quickly and efficiently, although it may not always lead to a satisfactory outcome for all parties involved.
In addition to these formal strategies, informal conflict resolution techniques can also be effective in the workplace. For example, having an open dialogue with the parties involved can help to identify the underlying causes of the conflict and develop a plan for resolving it. Another approach is to focus on building positive relationships between employees, which can help to prevent conflicts from arising in the first place.
Ultimately, the most effective strategy for conflict resolution in the workplace will depend on the specific circumstances of the conflict and the preferences of those involved. However, utilizing a range of techniques, including formal and informal approaches, can help to ensure that conflicts are resolved in a productive and respectful manner.

instruction: How can governments utilize fiscal and monetary policies to combat economic recessions?
output:
Fiscal and monetary policies are two main tools used by governments to combat economic recessions. Fiscal policy refers to the government’s taxing and spending decisions, while monetary policy involves changes in the interest rates or the money supply.
In terms of fiscal policy, governments can boost economic growth during a recession by increasing spending on public goods such as infrastructure, education, and healthcare. This increase in spending puts money into the economy, creating more jobs and stimulating economic activity. Governments can also reduce taxes, which allows individuals and businesses to keep more of their income, leading to increased consumer spending and investment.
Monetary policy involves changes in the interest rates set by the central bank. Lowering interest rates makes borrowing cheaper, encouraging businesses to invest and consumers to spend. This increases demand for goods and services, resulting in economic growth. The central bank can also increase the money supply by purchasing government bonds or other assets, which puts more money into the economy.
Both fiscal and monetary policies can be effective at combatting economic recessions, but they work best in tandem. For example, lowering interest rates can help stimulate economic growth, but if there is not enough spending to go around, the effects may be limited. Similarly, increasing spending on public goods can boost economic growth, but if there is not enough money in the economy to support this spending, the effects may be short-lived. A combination of the two policies can provide the most comprehensive solution to economic downturns.

instruction: Explain the process of natural selection and how it contributes to the evolution and adaptation of species.
output:
Examples of natural selection in action.
The process of natural selection is the driving force behind the evolution and adaptation of species over time. Natural selection is the mechanism by which certain traits become more or less common within a population through the passing down of genetic information from parents to their offspring.
Natural selection works by selecting for the traits that are most beneficial to the survival and reproductive success of a species in its environment. These beneficial traits are passed down to the next generation, allowing the species to adapt and evolve over time.
For example, consider a population of birds living in an environment where food is scarce. Birds with larger beaks are able to crack open tough nuts and seeds more easily than birds with smaller beaks. Over time, the larger beaked birds are more likely to survive and reproduce, passing on their larger beak size to their offspring. With each successive generation, the average beak size of the population increases until it becomes adapted to the local environment.
Another example is the peppered moth in England. Before the Industrial Revolution, the light-colored moth was more common because it blended in with the tree bark. However, as air pollution increased, the darker variant became more common due to its ability to blend in with soot-covered trees. This adaptation allowed the darker moths to survive and reproduce more successfully, passing on their dark coloration to their offspring.
In conclusion, natural selection is the process by which organisms adapt and evolve over time through the passing down of beneficial traits from parents to their offspring. It is driven by environmental pressures and allows species to become better adapted to their surroundings.

4. Making irrelevant or off-topic comments - When someone is confused or uninformed, they may make comments that are unrelated to the topic at hand or that don't add value to the conversation.
5. Asking for clarification frequently - People who are confused or uninformed may ask for clarification often, especially if the topic is complex or technical.
6. Interrupting or speaking over others - When someone is uncertain or confused, they may interrupt others or speak over them, which can be a sign that they are struggling to keep up with the conversation.
7. Having a lack of enthusiasm or interest - If someone is uninformed or confused, they may show a lack of enthusiasm or interest in the topic being discussed, which can be a subtle clue that they are struggling to understand.

instruction: In a world where automation is becoming increasingly prevalent, is it more important to prioritize job creation or technological progress?
output:
In recent years, there has been a lot of discussion around the potential impacts of automation on jobs and the workforce. Automation refers to the use of technology to automate tasks that would normally be done by humans, potentially leading to job losses and reduced demand for certain types of labor. However, many argue that automation also has the potential to create new job opportunities and drive economic growth. So, which is more important: prioritizing job creation or technological progress?
One perspective suggests that job creation should be prioritized over technological progress, as it provides more immediate benefits to society. By creating new jobs, people can support themselves and their families, which in turn contributes to economic growth and stability. Additionally, having a job can provide a sense of purpose and help individuals feel more connected to their communities.
On the other hand, some argue that technological progress should be prioritized over job creation, as it has the potential to create new industries, increase productivity, and drive innovation. This can lead to increased economic growth and improved living standards for everyone. Additionally, advances in technology can help address social issues such as poverty, inequality, and climate change.
Ultimately, it may not be possible to prioritize one over the other. Both job creation and technological progress are important for driving economic growth and improving society. Instead, policymakers and stakeholders should focus on finding ways to balance these two goals and ensure that the benefits of automation are shared equitably across society. This might involve investing in retraining programs and supporting workers who may be affected by job losses due to automation, as well as encouraging innovation and technological development to create new job opportunities and drive economic growth.

instruction: While using ```new_list = my_list```, any modifications to ```new_list``` changes ```my_list``` every time. Why is this, and how can I clone or copy the list to prevent it?
output:
Python lists are objects, and therefore they have a reference (or address) to the object that they point to. If you assign the variable "my_list" to a new list "new_list", you are creating a new reference to the same list object. Any modifications to "new_list" will change "my_list" as well as vice versa. To clone a list in Python, you can use the built-in function `copy.deepcopy()`. Here's an example:
```
my_list = [1, 2, 3]
new_list = copy.deepcopy(my_list)
print(my_list)
print(new_list)
# my_list -> [1, 2, 3]
# new_list -> [1, 2, 3]
```
In this example, both "my_list" and "new_list" point to the same list object initially. When we call `copy.deepcopy()`, we are creating a new reference to the same list object, but it is not pointing to "my_list". Now, any modifications to "new_list" will not affect "my_list".

How to learn Hebrew if you don’t live in Israel.
The 5 best places to visit in Israel.
Hebrew (עִבְרִית, pronounced [ivrit]) is a Semitic language of the Afro-Asiatic language family. Historically, it developed from the ancient Canaanite language which was spoken in the Levant region of the eastern Mediterranean coast of the former United States of Israel and the Kingdom of Judah. The earliest written evidence of Hebrew is a blessing from the 10th century BCE. The Hebrew alphabet, the second most used writing system in the world today, was originally a consonantal alphabet composed of 22 letters. It is written right to left, like Arabic; unlike Arabic, vowels are not usually indicated by separate letters but rather are understood from their context within the word, or sometimes by using matres lectionis. Modern Hebrew is one of the official languages of Israel, while Classical Hebrew is studied in Jewish religious establishments and has been the literary standard of Judaism for over two thousand years.

instruction: What would have happened if the South won the Civil War?
output:
What would have happened if the South won the Civil War?
The war had been going on since 1861. The Union, led by President Abraham Lincoln, was winning, but it looked like the Confederacy might win in the end. If the South had won, slavery would have continued, and the United States would have been split into two countries: the Confederate States of America (CSA) and the United States of America (USA). The CSA would have controlled all of the land south of the Mason-Dixon Line, which runs through Delaware and Maryland. The capital of the CSA would have been Richmond, Virginia.
The defeat of the Union at Gettysburg in July of 1863 effectively ended the Civil War for the North. If the South had won at Gettysburg, they would have gone on to capture Washington D.C., and the war would have ended with the South as the victors.
However, there are still many unanswered questions about what would have happened if the South had won the Civil War. For example, would slavery have been abolished? Would the United States have remained intact? What would have been the impact on American history? These are all questions that historians continue to debate.

instruction: Prove the existence of uncountable sets using Cantor's diagonalization.
output: The idea is to construct a function $f:\mathbb{N}\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$ such that $f(n)$ is the smallest positive integer not listed in $\{f(k):k\in\mathbb{N}\}$. This function can be defined recursively as $f(1)=2$ and $f(n+1)=f(n)+1$. The Cantor diagonal argument shows that there must be an $n_0$ such that $f(n_0)$ is not listed in $\{f(k):k\in\mathbb{N}\}$, as otherwise we could find a smaller $n_1$ with the same property. But this is impossible, since each $f(k)$ is either $f(n)$ or $f(n)+1$, so by the choice of $n_0$, $f(n_0)$ would have to be either $f(n_0-1)$ or $f(n_0)$, which is a contradiction. Therefore, $\mathbb{N}$ has more elements than any enumerable set.

instruction: What are some interesting periods in African history? Help me find a setting for my historical novel.

1. The slave trade led to the development of plantation economies in the New World, as well as significant cultural changes in Africa.
2. Scramble for Africa (late 19th Century) – This was a period of intense competition among European powers to gain control of African territory. This led to the partitioning of many African countries and the imposition of colonial rule, which would have lasting effects on the continent.
3. Anti-colonial movements and Independence (mid-20th Century) – This period saw a wave of nationalist movements and protests against colonial rule across Africa. Many countries gained independence in the 1960s and 1970s, leading to new governments, political systems, and societal structures.
4. Apartheid and the Struggle for Democracy (1948-1994) – This was a period of severe racial segregation and discrimination in South Africa, culminating in the institution of apartheid in 1948. The anti-apartheid movement was a global effort to end this system of racial oppression, and South Africa eventually transitioned to a multi-racial democracy in the 1990s.

instruction: Write a short story based on the following prompt:  “Ninja visibility peaked in the 1980’s, and as you can see it’s been on a steady decline since. The consensus of most ninjologists is that they’re extinct, but I disagree. I think they’ve perfected their technique. And I think I can prove it.”
output:
The year was 2087 and the world had changed drastically. Once mighty empires had fallen, while new nations rose from the ashes of old. The ninja clans had long since vanished from public view, their methods and secrets lost to history. But some said they were not gone forever, that they had merely adapted and evolved beyond the sight of mortal men.
Agent Smith worked for an organization dedicated to the study of the ninja, or “ninjologists” as they called themselves. He had been on a mission to Japan to investigate a possible sighting of a living ninja when his team received word of a breakthrough in their research.
“The consensus of most ninjologists is that they’re extinct,” his boss had told him over the comms unit, “but I disagree. I think they’ve perfected their technique. And I think I can prove it.”
Smith boarded a shuttle for Narita Airport, the site of what would surely be a historic discovery. As he walked down the jetway, he could feel the weight of the world on his shoulders. If he was right about this, it could mean a major breakthrough for his discipline, but if he was wrong… well, he didn’t like to think about that possibility.
As he entered the terminal, he felt a presence behind him. Without turning around, he knew it was her.
“I see you have brought the outsider,” a voice whispered in his ear.
Smith turned with a smile and bowed respectfully before his teacher, Master Kimoto.
“You must be careful, Agent Smith. The world is not what it once was. There are those who would seek to use our art for evil purposes. We must be vigilant if we are to preserve it for future generations.”
Smith nodded in understanding.

instruction: What propels vomit out of your stomach?
output: Vomit is forcefully expelled from the stomach through the esophagus as a result of nausea or an upset stomach. Vomiting can be triggered by a variety of factors, including consuming food or drink that does not agree with one's stomach, motion sickness, or illness. Nerve signals from the digestive system to the brain can cause nausea, and the brain responds by signaling the muscles in the esophagus and stomach to contract, forcing the contents of the stomach up and out of the body.

instruction: How much of sexual orientation is innate? Can being gay or straight be societally influenced?
output:
A new study suggests that sexual orientation may be somewhat innate.
Homosexuality has been the subject of much debate, starting from ancient Greece and continuing through the middle ages when homosexuals were persecuted, to the present day when it is a hotly debated topic. Many argue that sexual orientation is 100% innate and determined by one’s genes, while others contend that sexual orientation is very much influenced by society. A recent paper published in Science indicates that sexual orientation is probably somewhere in between – with some elements being strongly innate, but other aspects being influenced by societal conditions.
In this study, researchers led by Andrea Ganna at the Charité–Universitätsmedizin Berlin and the Max Planck Institute for Informatics in Saarbrücken conducted a large-scale analysis of genetic and epidemiological data in four populations: gay men, lesbian women, bisexual men, and heterosexual women. The study included over 465,000 participants and almost 3,000,000 SNPs (single nucleotide polymorphisms that are variations in DNA sequence). They found that there are likely several genetic factors that influence sexual orientation, including one located near the X chromosome. This same gene was also linked to sexually dimorphic brain structures in the hypothalamus and amygdala. These two areas are involved in processing emotions and are known to differ in males and females.
“People can change their sexual orientation given social circumstances.”
The results of this study indicate that, for the majority of individuals, sexual behavior develops along a continuum with heterosexuality at one end, and homosexuality at the other. However, sexual orientation is probably not so easily changed as indicated by the fact that most people stay within the same approximate location on the continuum

instruction: If electric turbos are a thing why cant exhaust gasses be used to generate electricity for the car?
output:
There are two ways to do this. One is by using a turbine, like in a jet engine and the other is by using a micro-combustion cell.
The turbine would need to be very efficient and small, but that technology already exists for electric generators on aircraft.
The micro-combustion cell would be a small chamber with a spark plug-like electrode in it. As gasses flow past it, they ionize and form an electrical current. This system would produce very little power but it would not require any moving parts.
I have seen both of these concepts before and I think they are both interesting.

instruction: why cant we send a space rover on an asteroid and just leave it there using the asteroid’s “orbit” to enter other galaxies?
output: There are several reasons why we can’t do this. First, interstellar space is vast and empty. An asteroid would have to be very big and very close to Earth to provide enough momentum for a rover to travel at significant fractions of the speed of light. Second, even if we could find an asteroid with that much momentum, it’s unlikely that any asteroid is going to come close enough to another galaxy for us to observe it. Finally, even if we could send a rover to another galaxy, it would take hundreds of years for it to get there. By the time the rover got there, our technology and understanding of physics would likely have advanced by so much that we wouldn’t need to send a rover anymore. We could simply calculate where we want it to go and beam the data to it directly.

The Indus Valley Civilization is one of these. It lasted from 2500 BCE to 1700 BCE, and was centered in what is now Pakistan and northwest India. We know less about it than we do about other ancient civilizations, because so few written records remain. However, its cities were well-planned and built with standardized brick houses - something no other ancient civilization did.

output: Planets orbiting twin stars are possible. They would orbit both stars at the same time, rather than one star like in our solar system. This is because a double star system has two stars orbiting each other. If there were planets in the system, they would likely orbit both stars as well. This type of system is known as a circumbinary system.

instruction: Why do most plastics turn white when you bend them?
output:
Ever wondered why plastic bends white?
When you bend a plastic, it is stretched. The molecules in the plastic are held together by weak forces called van der Waals forces. When you stretch them, these forces become weaker and the molecules move apart. This causes the plastic to turn white. The same thing happens when you pull a rubber band – it turns white because the van der Waals forces become weaker.

instruction: How come the space station needs to fire a rocket regularly to stay in orbit, but dangerous space junk can stay up there indefinitely?
output:
There's a lot of space junk in orbit around the Earth. In fact, it's estimated that there are more than 20,000 objects larger than a softball and millions of smaller pieces of debris orbiting our planet. While most of this space junk is harmless, it can still pose a serious threat to astronauts and spacecraft.
One of the biggest threats posed by space junk is the risk of collision. If two pieces of debris were to collide, the energy released could cause further damage to other objects in the area. This is why the International Space Station (ISS) needs to perform avoidance maneuvers every now and then. To put it simply, it doesn't want to become space junk itself!
So, how come the space station needs to fire its thrusters to stay in orbit, but dangerous space junk can stay up there indefinitely? The answer lies in the size of the objects. Most of the space junk orbiting Earth is too small to be tracked or cataloged, so we don't know much about it. However, we do know that most of this debris is less than 1 centimeter in size.
The ISS, on the other hand, is a large and relatively heavy object that requires a lot of fuel to keep it in orbit. Unlike the space junk, which is mostly harmless, the ISS poses a significant risk to any other object it collides with. That's why it needs to perform avoidance maneuvers to keep itself safe.

instruction: How do remote tribes that have no new genetic material for thousands of years not die out because of inbreeding?
output:
How do remote tribes that have no new genetic material for thousands of years not die out because of inbreeding?
This question is based on the premise that "inbreeding leads to genetic disorders", which can be true in certain circumstances. However, there are many cultures and societies that practice endogamy (marrying within their own group) without facing these problems. One example is the Hutterite communities in North America, where there is a high degree of consanguinity (relationship between close genetic relatives) among married couples. A study conducted on the Hutterites found that they experience no increased rates of congenital disabilities compared to the general population.
Another example is the Lepcha people of Sikkim, India, who have a highly endogamous mating system. A study conducted on this population found that they have no significant differences in their health outcomes compared to other populations in India.
These examples demonstrate that inbreeding itself is not necessarily harmful, and that other factors such as strong cultural practices, good healthcare systems, and social support networks can help mitigate any potential negative effects.

instruction: Are there any academic fields that don't have enough people trying to teach?
output:
Sociology and Anthropology are two such fields.
The majority of the college students I know who are studying these disciplines are doing so because they have no clear career goals, and their parents told them that they should study something "easy" (since both of these subjects are relatively easy to understand, while not requiring much actual skill or practice to do them well).
More people should be studying these subjects, but they don't really have practical use outside of academia. But we could make them more practical by teaching people skills like how to apply for jobs and write resumes.
I don't think it is a problem of too few interested students. Rather it is a problem of too few professors willing to teach these subjects. There aren't many places in the world where you can get a job with a degree in sociology or anthropology unless you also majored in something else. And even if you managed to find a job in your field, it wouldn't be very prestigious. So why would anyone want to become a professor in either of those fields?
Anthropology isn't exactly lacking in practitioners... it's just that most anthropologists are working as consultants for various government agencies or large corporations rather than on university faculties. The Bureau of Labor Statistics classifies anthropologists as "social scientists," and estimates that there were 23,500 of them employed in the US in 2014. Most of them are employed as follows:

instruction: How can I convince people that the use of instant messaging platforms like Slack, and Hipchat are not a good substitute for documentation?
output:
What I'm talking about is that people are using those platforms to document processes and procedures.
Instant Messaging platforms like Slack or Hipchat while being very good at what they do (which is communicating in real-time) are horrible at documenting anything because:
They lack version control
Their messages are ephemeral by nature, they don't persist over time
They lack a structure for creating reusable elements
They lack natural language parsing which makes it difficult to search for keywords
Using an Instant Messaging platform to document things is not a good idea because when you need to look something up later you will have no idea where to look. When having to refer someone else to a procedure you will have no idea where to send them. When a new team member joins the team and has to read through all previous discussions to get up to speed on how to perform his/her tasks you can imagine how unworkable this would be.
So my question is: How can I convince people that the use of instant messaging platforms like Slack, and Hipchat are not a good substitute for documentation?
instant-messaging documentation chat tools
Documentation should be documented somewhere, not as a series of conversations in a channel. If you want to use a particular tool, then use it for documentation, not for communication.
If you have a process which needs to be documented then create a wiki page for it - preferably one that is not a part of your IM system, but rather a standalone wiki installation running on your own server or on github pages. This gives you version control, a proper revision history, the ability to link to other pages, etc.
If you really want to keep logs of conversations then do so in another system, either a forum or a separate log system. Using an IM system to record conversations means that important information will be lost if the

instruction: The HR director requested monetary contributions for a Christmas present for one of the upper management employees. What are your thoughts when HR asks employees for money as a gift?

The fact that they asked you for money tells me that they are out of ideas. This person may have been someone who has been with the company for a long time and you want to give them something special but you can't just ask for money. What about an experience?
Maybe you can get this person tickets to a sporting event or a play or a concert. A gift card is easy and it gives them options. You could also simply give them a check for a set amount of money that they could use any way that they want.
It sounds like they are asking for cash because it is easier than trying to get everyone to contribute to a gift basket or something else. While it might be okay if this was a newer employee that nobody knows well, it just doesn't feel right when it comes to someone who has been with the company for a while.
Maybe there is something you could do instead, even if it involves a small expense on your part. Perhaps you could get together a group of people and purchase a gift. Or, you could take the person out to lunch and let everyone buy their own. That way, no one feels obligated to contribute financially and you aren't giving money as a gift.

instruction: Can a company ask you to leave, push you for an exit date, say they “cannot” lay you off and have to train replacement?
output:
Can an employer force you out?
New York, NY – Can an employer force you out? Yes, although there are some limits on how they can do it. The federal WARN Act protects employees from layoffs if they have been employed at a facility for at least six months and worked for the company for at least one year. If the circumstances meet the WARN Act’s requirements, then you are entitled to 60 calendar days notice before a covered mass layoff or plant closing. There are exceptions to this rule, however.
The WARN Act does not apply to every employer. It only applies to:
Private-sector companies that employ at least 100 workers; and
Government entities that employ at least 50 workers.
In addition, the WARN Act does not apply to most workers unless they have been employed at their company for at least six months. So, if you have only been working at your job for a few weeks, then you would not be protected by the law.
The WARN Act does not require employers to provide severance pay or any other form of compensation to workers who lose their jobs because of a covered mass layoff or plant closing. However, if your state has its own version of the WARN Act, then you may be entitled to additional benefits.
If you are facing a possible layoff at work, then you should talk to an experienced employment lawyer right away. Your attorney can explain whether the WARN Act applies to your situation and help you understand your rights under the law. They can also help you determine if you may be eligible for additional benefits under state law.

output:
I am currently reading a book from the 1970's that seems to be describing some cutting edge research. It is all in French and I don't read French. From the bibliographies it looks like there has been some response to this book. However, I have no way of knowing if these responses are positive or negative.
My question: How can I as a non-academic know if a book is widely used and well accepted by scholars?
publications citations
In general, you need to look at citation metrics. For books, the most common metric is the number of citations the book has received (either directly or indirectly via secondary sources), which you can find using services such as Google Scholar or Microsoft Academic. The problem here is that textbooks tend to get fewer citations than more research focused monographs. – Nate Eldredge Jul 30 '14 at 21:44
@NateEldredge Good points. I guess I'm looking for a definitive list of widely used texts. I suppose I could ask around on social media but I thought there might be an easier answer. – JWK Jul 30 '14 at 22:04
You could also try asking this question on Academia.SE. The scope of that site includes academics in all fields, so you may get a better response there. – Nate Eldredge Jul 30 '14 at 22:08
Separately, you could also try contacting the author directly, or even the publisher. – Nate Eldredge Jul 30 '14 at 22:10
Also, you could consult the review section on Amazon.com (or the equivalent on the website of your local bookstore). – Nate Eldredge Jul

instruction: Is it fair to call Superman a hero when 99% of the time he puts himself at no risk by saving people?
output:
Is it fair to call Superman a hero when 99% of the time he puts himself at no risk by saving people?
I'm not sure what you mean by "when 99% of the time he puts himself at no risk". Batman is an example of a superhero who does put himself in serious danger, but Superman usually doesn't. That doesn't make him any less of a hero. – James McLeod Aug 28 '14 at 15:26
Superman is a hero because he does good things without expecting anything in return. If he didn't put himself at risk then he would be no better than a normal person i.e. an everyday hero. He is better than that and works for the greater good. – user3918 Aug 28 '14 at 15:30
Superman isn't a perfect hero, but I would still consider him one. While he does sometimes go out of his way to avoid harm, he has also been known to put himself in harm's way for the greater good. Just think of how many times he's willingly fought Doomsday, or Darkseid, or other villains who could easily kill him. Even if he always had a 100% chance of winning, it's the principle of the thing. – Mike Harris Aug 28 '14 at 17:01
Well, they do say that heroes aren't perfect, they just fight the imperfection within themselves. – AncientSwordRage Aug 28 '14 at 19:28
@MikeHarris And there are plenty of examples of Superman actually putting himself at risk (at least temporarily) for the sake of others, see here) – user3918 Aug 28 '1

instruction: What are some of the commonly held misconceptions about any of the American Indian/Native American cultural groups?
output:
What are some of the commonly held misconceptions about any of the American Indian/Native American cultural groups?
Some common misconceptions about Native Americans include believing that they live in teepees, do not pay taxes, and are collectively known as "Indians." These stereotypes can cause people to overlook the diverse cultures found within Indigenous communities.

instruction: How should I do time manage spreading time working on multiple projects? For example, should I "time block" your calendar and say 8am to 10am I work Project A. And 10am to 11am I work on Project B. What are other methods besides time blocking?
output:
For example, you could use the Pomodoro Technique. There are also other time management techniques that will help with multitasking and focusing on multiple tasks:
1. The Eisenhower Matrix divides tasks into four quadrants depending on their urgency and how important they are. Tasks in the upper right are things you should do immediately, those in the upper left are tasks you can do later, tasks in the lower right are tasks that can be delegated to others, and those in the lower left are tasks that aren't worth doing at all. Prioritize according to this matrix and tackle the upper right first.
2. One of the best ways to stop multitasking is to batch similar tasks together. For example, if you are working on several reports, create a playlist of songs or podcasts to listen to while you do all of them.
3. Learning to say "no" and setting boundaries around your time is an important skill for effective time management. If you feel overworked and overwhelmed, think about what you can stop doing so you have more time to focus on the tasks that really matter.
4. Instead of working on multiple projects at once, you could work on them one after the other. This might be necessary if you only have enough bandwidth to complete one task at a time.

instruction: I'm buying a car for the first time, any advice?
output:
Good question, and many people are in your shoes. First time car buyers often find the experience overwhelming, with so many options out there to choose from, but hopefully this article will help make things easier for you. We'll discuss everything you need to know when buying a car, from researching cars and negotiating your deal, to arranging finance and taking delivery of your new vehicle.
So let's begin with breaking down the process into stages.
Step 1 - Figure out how much you can afford to spend on your new car and what features you want it to have.
Step 2 - Research cars online and figure out which ones you'd like to take for a test drive.
Step 3 - Organise a test drive of each of the cars you're interested in.
Step 4 - Work out which dealership has the best prices on the cars you're interested in.
Step 5 - Decide on your favourite car and arrange a second test drive if required.
Step 6 - Discuss the price with the dealer and decide on any extras you may want to add.
Step 7 - Finalise the deal by signing the paperwork and arranging delivery or collection of your new car.
Step 8 - Have the car delivered and inspect it carefully before driving away.
Now that you've chosen your new car you need to arrange finance. How you arrange your finance will depend on whether you're paying cash or needing to take out a loan.
If you're paying in full, you can either take the money with you to the dealership, or transfer it to their bank account first thing in the morning. If you need a loan, then you have two main options - a personal loan from your bank, or a car loan from the dealership themselves.
Bank loans

instruction: Are there parallels between the use of radio communication by nationalists in the 1930’s and the use of social media/Twitter by nationalists in the present day? Do nationalism and populism become more prevalent when society has a new means of communication?
output: Not necessarily. I believe that the use of social media by nationalists is a reflection of the rise of nationalism in general, which has been on the rise since the 1990s. Social media just provides an easier way for people to connect with each other and spread their ideas.
